titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Finished reading Dallas’s Reports of Cases adjudged in the Courts of the United States— In the afternoon read, the 6th: Book of Thucydides— These Books have so completely engaged my time since I began them, as to leave me no superfluous leisure.— This afternoon and evening, Mr: E. Glover, Mr: T. Greenleaf, Captain Beale and B. Adams were here in succession— I took my usual walk— Mr: Savage took a portrait of my father, to introduce in a picture of the Declaration of Independence upon which he is engaged— He dined with us— My brother was abroad, almost all day.

2. My brother went this morning to Dedham, to attend the Supreme Court sitting there this week— I began to read Mr: Cranch’s Reports of the Cases adjudged in U.S. Supreme Court, since they have held their Sessions at Washington. In the afternoon read the 7th: Book of Thucydides— The 6th: and 7th: Books contain the whole Account of the Great Sicilian expedition.— In the Evening I read part of a Canto of Hudibras.

3. Mr: Quincy was here this morning, and urged me to consent to stand as a Candidate for the Office of President of the University— Upon which I could only repeat the answer I gave him when he mentioned it to me last Week.
I then supposed him joking— But he was this day very serious— It will not answer— They are still to choose a member of the Corporation and a Professor of Divinity— Quincy opened to me more fully the real causes of their former delays, and the personal and family views which enter into these elections.— Mr: Black was here this afternoon with a Mr: M’Intire, a brother of Mr: G. W. M’Intire; upon business.— Read the curious case of Marbury and Madison, in Cranch’s Reports— Finish’d reading Thucydides, in Smith’s translation— I hope one day to read the original— It has given me the only accurate idea of the 21 earliest years of the Pelopponnesian War— Walk’d— Call’d at Mr: Cranch’s, where I found two letters from my wife— On coming home, found my brother, return’d from Dedham, to go back to-morrow.— Read the 2d: Canto of Hudibras Part 3d:— In which the author leaves his Hero, to tell the Catastrophe of the Rump Parliament.

4. My brother, went again to Dedham— I went in to Boston— Call’d at Mr: Freeman’s; respecting the publication of the next Volume of the Historical Society.— At Mr: Dexter’s Office, but he is not in Town. At Mr: Shaw’s— Branch Bank, and at the Academy’s Room; where I took a list of the Societies and Universities, to which the Volumes of the transactions are to be sent. Met there Dr: Lathrop and Mr: Freeman— Dined at Judge Davis’s—with Mr: Emerson and Dr. Kirkland. and Mr: I. P. Davis— After dinner Call’d at Mr: Foster’s, and at Whitcomb’s— Return’d in the Evening to Quincy— My Mother quite unwell— Judge Davis and Dr: Kirkland, talk’d to me about the Presidency of the University.

5. Continued to read Mr: Cranch’s reports— In the afternoon, read part of T. Morton’s Book; and consulted Priestley’s lectures on History.— Walk’d down to Mr: Quincy’s in the Evening, and lent him the volume containing Morton, and Wood, and the Wonder-working Providence— Finish’d reading Hudibras.

6. My Mother is very ill— I finished Mr: Cranch’s reports, and read part of the Appendix— Dined with Mr: Quincy. Mr: Gardner the clergyman, of Boston, and Mr: Nicholls were there— Mr: Nicholls brought me, for the Academy, the Transactions of the American Philosophical Society—Vol 6. Part 1—recently published— My brother return’d this Evening from Dedham— His name is this day first held up in the newspaper as Candidate for Congress at the next Election; from the County of Norfolk.— Not with any chance of success; but because he will probably be run as high, as any man in the District of the same opinions.

7. As Mr: Whitney had given notice there was no preaching this day, and I pass’d it at home— Reading in Butler’s Analogy, and writing to my wife— In the Evening I went up to Mr: Cranch’s— Mr: Barrett, and Mr: Bracket were there.— My Mother continues very unwell.

8. My brother and Louisa Smith went to Boston, and return’d this Evening.— They went to attend the funeral of Mrs: Green, a Sister of Mr: Foster’s. I finished reading the Appendix to Mr: Cranch’s Reports— And began upon Robinson’s Admiralty Reports.— The afternoon I wasted in something very like idleness— Walk’d in the Evening, and read the Abridgment of the History of New-England, by Dr: Morse and Mr: Parish.

9. This day a Brigade of Militia were to have been reviewed on the plain, this side of Neponsit Bridge; and I had an invitation from the General and Field Officers, to dine with them at Mr: Billings’s— But although the Sun rose clear, and the early part of the morning promised fair weather, it began to rain by 9 A.M. and very soon a S.E. Storm blew up, which raged with extreme violence the whole day. Towards Night the wind changed to N.E. but the fury of the tempest increased instead of abating— It continued the whole evening, and untill I went late to bed, and slept upon it— The house trembled under it— I was of course confined the whole day; & read variously— Robinson— The transactions of the American Philosophical Society— Aikin’s Annual Review; Sotheby’s Georgics, and Dr: Morse & Mr: Parish—

10. The tempest continued in all its violence through the greatest part of the Night; and has but partially subsided this morning— A Master of a Vessel cast away on the neighbouring beach came and made a protest before my brother this forenoon.— Another came for the same purpose this afternoon; but my brother was gone to Milton. Mr: Quincy Thaxter early this morning called to borrow a horse to go home— He had come yesterday in the Hingham packet to attend the Review; but was driven ashore last Night, and remained on board the vessel untill this morning— I went up to my house before dinner, and on the way saw more than a hundred trees, of all sizes torn up by the roots, or shattered into fragments— Windows blown down, roofs blown away; Pratt’s shop and shed levell’d to the ground, and other marks of the most violent storm I ever witness’d upon the land. My brother met similar marks of devastation on the road to Milton— One of my own barns has lost part of its roof.— The storm has continued though with less violence, all this day and Evening— Reading as yesterday— Received a letter from my wife.

11. As the time for my departure has drawn very near, I am obliged to abandon my customary morning occupation of reading, and make the necessary preparations for my journey.— This day the weather softened and cleared away.— In the Evening I went to Mr: Cranch’s.— Read some letters of Dr: Priestly, in the Philadelphia Transactions, and finished the Abridged History of New-England.

12. Mr: G. Apthorp here this morning— Mr: and Mrs: Quincy and Miss Morton at tea this afternoon, and Mr: and Mrs: Black— In the Evening I went to Mr: Cranch’s.— Spent the day chiefly in finishing off several concerns previous to my departure— Letter from Mr: W. Bartlett, Newbury-Port.

13. Went in to Boston this morning with Mrs: Cranch— Was employed in business of sundry kinds— Call’d at Mr: Shaw’s and Mr: Dexter’s Offices— Mr: Dexter thinks nothing can be done with Mrs: Hall’s business, untill the papers come— At the Branch Bank— Mr: Dalton took my bills, and must credit me for the Amount— Engaged my passage to Providence for next Wednesday.— Dined at Mr: Smith’s. Mr: Otis’s family— Mr: & Mrs: Parsons, Mrs: Peabody and her daughter, Mrs: Cranch &c there— Mrs: Edwards came in after dinner— This afternoon I met Mr: Fessenden the Poet, at Shaw’s Office— Returned to Quincy, with Mrs Peabody and Abby, and Mrs: Cranch—

14. Heard Mr: Whitney— His Communion day— Wrote to Mrs: Adams— Engaged all the remainder of the day in packing, preparing and making arrangements— In the Evening I went to Mr: Cranch’s. Finished reading, La Berthe’s letters on Senegal— Mr: Shaw came out from Boston— Whitcomb too was here to borrow some plate.

15. Mr: Apthorp was here this morning, and again in the Evening— I drew for him an Indenture, in three parts, which we are to execute to-morrow. It employed me very closely. My brother went to Randolph, and returned at Night. Mr: R. C. Beale was here this afternoon on some business he wishes to have done at Washington— I sent to Boston my Trunks, which were embarked in the Brig Katy, for Alexandria— The son and daughter of Mr: B. Vaughan were here at dinner.

16. I came into Boston this morning, with Mr: G. Apthorp. We executed the papers of his second conveyance in trust to Mr: James Lloyd junr: Mr: John Prince junr: and myself— I finished the business relative to the bills of Exchange on Messrs: Willink.— Transacted various other business necessary, to be finished before my departure— Dined at Judge Dawes’s; and accepted the offer of a bed at Mr: Smith’s.— In the Evening, called at Mr: W. Sullivan’s—to give him all the information I could, concerning G. W. M’Intire’s business.

17. At 8 this Morning I took the Stage for Providence— Just as we were ready to Start from Concert-Hall, Dr: Waterhouse, arrived from Cambridge, with his Sister, who went on with us— Our Carriage was full of Company, none of whom were however known to me— We dined at Walpole, and arrived at Providence, at about 5 in the afternoon. We stopp’d at Aldrich’s— But he with his family, were absent. Had there been a Packet here ready to sail for New-York, it was my intention to proceed with her— One had sailed this afternoon, a few hours before we arrived; and one is to sail to-morrow, but stops at Newport, and will of course be detained there a Night— So I concluded to go on by land to New-London.

18. At 5 this morning, we left Providence in the Stage, travelling a road over which I had never been before.— We breakfasted at Scituate, in Rhode-Island; and entering the State of Connecticut shortly after, dined at Norwich, and arrived just at dusk, at New-London— The distance from Providence is 56 miles— The roads rough, and rocky; indifferently kept up, though charged with turnpike tolls— Of the Passengers who came with me from Boston, one only came on beyond Providence, and terminated his journey at Norwich— Others took the vacant places, but I had only two fellow passengers on entering New-London, and they are to go no further— I put up with the Stage at Frink’s: the same house, at which we pass’d a day, when we came in here in the Providence Packet last year. I find myself again disappointed of a passage to New-York by water— There are four packets that ply regularly between this place and that— Two of them are at New-York, detained by the present winds, and the other two sailed last Night with a company of English and German Passengers, who were coming from London to New-York in an American vessel—the Iris—Captain Skinner; but landed at New-London in a Pilot-Boat, from fear of impressment, by one of the British frigates cruizing upon our Coast.— We had a bad day for travelling— Rain & Storm all the Morning. but an excellent Wind for Water Passage to New-York.

19. I left New-London at 5 this morning, alone in the Stage— Cross’d Connecticut River at Saybrook, where I breakfasted— A very beautiful and agreeable young Lady, whose name I believe was Harris, took a seat here, for New-Haven, and we were soon after joined by a young Englishman, and two Germans, of the Company landed from the Ship Iris— In the course of the day, we pass’d by several others of them— We dined at Guilford, and arrived at New-Haven before Sun-set— I went immediately with the Passengers from England down to the wharf, to enquire again for a water-passage to New-York, but was again unsuccessful. There are twelve regular Packets, which sail between this and New-York— They depart every evening, each in its turn— But if either of them lose its turn, by not being here when the day comes, it must wait untill its turn comes round again— Such is the case with that which was to have sailed this Evening— It is still detained by head-winds at New-York— To-morrow Evening another will go; but as this would detain us here the whole day, we concluded to continue in the Stage— Lodg’d at Nicholls’s, an indifferent house— I met here an old Lady who resides at Jamaica-Plains, near Boston, and told me of all her acquaintance there— We had a very fine day for travelling, and the roads are generally good— The distance from New-London to New-Haven is 48 Miles.

20. Between 4 and 5 this morning we started from New-Haven; with the Englishman; and two Germans mentioned yesterday— A Ship-Captain, who had arrived alone in the Stage from Hartford, and several others, who travell’d with us only part of the day— We breakfasted at Stratford 16 Miles from New-Haven— Then went through Fairfield, 20 miles more to Norwalk, to dinner; and thence through Stamford, over Horse-Neck, and Byrom river, which divides the States of Connecticut and New-York, 18 Miles to Rye.— Before dark we got in, at Penfield’s; a very good house— The day has been very fine— The roads, excepting over horse-Neck, good— Distance travell’d 54 miles. The Inn at Rye, was full of travellers, to and from New-York.

21. We took our departure this morning not so early as usual, just before Sun-rise, and rode 12 miles to Breakfast at East-Chester— Armstrong’s—an indifferent House— Thence through Haerlem to New-York the distance is charged for eighteen miles— The turnpikes however have shortened each of these distances more than two miles. The Stage-fare remaining the same as before to compensate the payment of the toll— We arrived in New-York at 11. o’clock
The Stage stopp’d at the City Hotel, in Broadway—as I was going to my Sister Smith’s, I met her eldest Son William, who went with me— The Coll: Was at his Mother’s at Newark— She has been for some weeks very dangerously ill; but is now recovering— Coll: Smith returned however this Evening. I call’d to see Mr: M’Cormick, and also Mr: Fitch, whom I did not find at home— I wrote a letter to my wife.

22. I called with Coll: Smith on Mr: Ebenr: Stevens, to inquire whether he had received Mr: W. Bartlett’s papers relative to the debt of R. Bird to him— But he had not— Thence we went to the Academy of Arts, where they have a number of models from Antique Statues, and where I met Mr: Murray; the gentleman with whom we were acquainted at Berlin— I called in the morning and again in the Evening at Mr: Aspinwall’s—concerning the choice of new Assignees, of R. Bird—for which purpose there is to be a meeting of the creditors to’morrow— Coll: Smith, dined, and pass’d the Evening abroad—

23. Mr: Murray, breakfasted with us at Coll: Smith’s— I called on Mr: M. L. Davis and Mr: J. B. Graves— Had a meeting of R. Bird’s Creditors, and chose an entire new set of Assignees— Messrs: G. Aspinwall, Ferguson, and J. O. Hoffman. I engaged a seat in the Stage— Industry line, to leave New-York for Philadelphia, at 8 O’Clock to-morrow morning. I applied at the Water-Stage Office to Burlington— But that goes only four times in the week—Mondays, Wednesday’s Thursdays and Fridays— Mr: Fitch dined at the Coll’s: and sat with us untill far into the Evening— I wrote a letter to my father

24. At 8 this morning I crossed the ferry at Powles Hoek— Among the passengers in the boat was Mr: Folwell, a printer in Philadelphia; a curious personage— He was going to Philadelphia, but in a different line of Stages, from ours; called the Diligence— The two Carriages started together— I found in the Stage at setting out a french-man who spoke no English, and two women, one of whom left us at Newark— Here we were joined by three members of the legislature of New-Jersey, going to Trenton, where it is now in Session— It rained all the morning, and the Stage did not stop long enough at Newark, to allow me to call at Mrs: Smith’s— We dined at Woodbridge, 26 miles, from New-York, and through Brunswick came to Princeton 28 Miles further, where we are to Lodge— At Striker’s. In the Evening, I had much conversation with our french fellow passenger, whose name is Bonnet, and who has resided twelve years in this Country; chiefly at Baltimore— Thither he is now returning— He was one of the refugees from St: Domingo in the year 1793. and has ever since remained here.

25. It was scarcely 4 this morning when we left Princeton, and rode to Breakfast 12 Miles to Trenton— Here the Members of the New-Jersey Legislature left us— But other passengers soon took their places— The woman we have in Company, is a young Irish widow, who lost her husband at New-York, about a fortnight since, and is going to some of her relations at Philadelphia— At Trenton they are building a Bridge over the river Delaware, and the Turnpike from Philadelphia is now finished, about ten miles from the City— From Trenton through Bristol to Philadelphia, is thirty miles. We arrived at 1/2 past 1. o’clock, and stop’d at the sign of Franklin’s Head in North Second-Street— Here I dined, and immediately after went out to deliver my letters— I called twice at Maxwell’s, and twice at Mr: Dennie’s lodgings, with the intent to see him but did not find him— Pass’d a couple of hours at Dr: Rush’s; and at the earnest invitation of Mr: and Mrs: Rutter, took at their house the bed which my brother formerly occupied— Called at Hardy’s to enquire, of the departure of the Land Stages to Baltimore, and at the Market-Street ferry, of that of the Water-Stage, through Newcastle and French-town.— The Pilot-Stage goes at 6. The Mail at 8 and the hour fixed for the departure of the Packet to Newcastle is likewise 8— I determined to go by land or by water as the wind and weather of the morning should recommend.

26. The wind being fair this morning, for the Packet to Newcastle, I determined to take passage in it; and after breakfasting with Mr: Rutter, embarked at 8 o’clock— But it was past 9 before we sailed— Mr: Bonnet had also taken passage in the same vessel. There were many passengers besides— Among the rest Captain Shaw of the
U.S. navy, with his wife and child— We had bad weather, and a violent storm of wind; but so fair that we were only three hours in running the 40 miles, and landed at Newcastle just after 12 o’clock— But on our arrival we found none of the French-town Stages ready to take us on; and were obliged to stay here the remainder of the day— At a very indifferent Inn— The Storm increased all the afternoon, and raged with great violence at Night— The House was crowded with the travellers to and from Baltimore, and I had a very bad bed in a room, with eight or nine others— Mr: Bonnet met here one of his Countrymen, going to Philadelphia—& they disagreed much in their politics— Bonnet had the worst of the Cause, and the best of the Argument.

27. At about 1 o’clock in the morning, the storm ceased, the wind came round to the North-West, and it became quite cold— Just before Six the Stages for French-town took us up— We found considerable ice in the road on the way. At about 10 we reached French-town, breakfasted, and went on board the Packet for Baltimore lying at the wharf. Just at Noon, the tide having risen sufficiently for the vessel to float, she set sail.— The wind was very light, and soon came round to the South-west, or directly a-head for our course— The progress we made therefore was very slow— In the Evening several of the Passengers made a party at loo, which they kept up untill 3 in the morning. I amused myself with a volume of Lady Montague’s works, recently published, and which I purchased at New-York, as a present to my wife.

28. We made slow progress in the Night, and this morning had very light and contrary winds— These gradually died away, and from noon untill near Midnight when we arrived at Baltimore, we had almost a dead calm. The weather was remarkably fine— The last 8 or 10 miles we performed chiefly by rowing and towing the vessel— On landing I went immediately to Evans’s— At the Indian Queen, and with some difficulty obtained a lodging there.

29. At 8 this morning we left Baltimore in the Georgetown Stage, dined atand arrived at Washington just at Sunset— There were in the Stage two Ladies, whose brother was travelling the road on horseback; and two sons of General Wilkinson, who with his family intends to pass the winter at Washington— There was also one other passenger.— I landed at the Stage-Office at George town, and immediately came over to Mr: Hellen’s, where I had the happiness to find my wife and children, and all the family well.— Mr: Sheldon was here in the Evening.

30. Pass’d the fore-part of the day chiefly in writing— Walk’d over to Georgetown, with my eldest child, George; in the afternoon I took a ride on Horseback, with my wife; and went some way beyond the Capitol. In the Evening Mr: Boyd was here.

31. Paid Visits to the President, and Mr: Madison; both of whom I found at home. The President conversed with me respecting the impressments by the British frigates upon our Coast; and respecting the trade carried on by some of the merchants with the Blacks at St: Domingo— This he appears determined to suppress, and I presume a Law will pass for the purpose at the approaching Session— I called also at Mr: Gallatin’s Office, at the Treasury, but he was not there— Met Mr: Cranch, Captain Tingey, and Mr: Deblois in the Streets.— In the Evening, there was company here at Tea— Mrs: Cunningham— Coll: Burroughs and his daughter Mrs: Thompson, and a Miss Roberts— Coll: Burroughs is much out of health.
Day. The first fortnight of the month, as the last— From the 15th: to the 30th.—travelling from Quincy to this place—
